title: Henry of Navarre (horse)
text:
Henry of Navarre (1891–1917) was an American <a href="National%20Museum%20of%20Racing%20and%20Hall%20of%20Fame">Hall of Fame</a> <a href="Thoroughbred">Thoroughbred</a> <a href="Eclipse%20Award">Champion</a> <a href="horse%20racing">racehorse</a>.
Background.
Henry of Navarre was sired by the 1884 <a href="Preakness%20Stakes">Preakness Stakes</a> winner <a href="Knight%20of%20Ellerslie">Knight of Ellerslie</a> he was named for the <a href="Huguenot">Huguenot</a> <a href="List%20of%20French%20monarchs">king</a>, <a href="Henry%20IV%20of%20France">Henry IV of France</a>. He was purchased by <a href="horse%20trainer">trainer</a> <a href="Byron%20McClelland">Byron McClelland</a>.
Racing career.
At age three Henry of Navarre won nine races in a row including the <a href="Belmont%20Stakes">Belmont Stakes</a>, in which he defeated another future Hall of Fame colt, <a href="Domino%20%28horse%29">Domino</a>, who had beaten him in the <a href="Withers%20Stakes">Withers Stakes</a>. After winning the <a href="Travers%20Stakes">Travers Stakes</a>, his handlers and <a href="James%20R.%20Keene">James R. Keene</a>, owner of Domino, agreed to a match race in which the horses ended up in a <a href="Tie%20%28draw%29">dead heat</a>. As such, they met again three weeks later in a race to determine the 1894 championship. For this championship event, the 4-year-old <a href="Clifford%20%28horse%29">Clifford</a> joined the two younger colts. Henry of Navarre beat his rivals by 3/4 length, earning Horse of the Year honors.
In 1895 McLelland offered to match Henry of Navarre against any horse in the world over one mile for any sum from $5,000 to $25,000 at <a href="weight-for-age">weight-for-age</a>.
Sold later in 1895 to prominent horseman <a href="August%20Belmont%20Jr.">August Belmont Jr.</a>, Henry of Navarre repeated as the U.S. Champion under future Hall of Fame trainer <a href="John%20Hyland%20%28horse%20trainer%29">John Hyland</a>. At age six, he was retired after winning the <a href="Suburban%20Handicap">Suburban Handicap</a>.
Stud career.
Retired to stand at <a href="horse%20breeding">stud</a> in <a href="France">France</a> he met with little success and in 1911, along with several other horses, was donated to the <a href="U.S.%20Army%20Remount%20Service">U.S. Army Remount Service</a> to help establish a national breeding program at the <a href="Front%20Royal%2C%20Virginia">Front Royal, Virginia</a> depot.
In 1985, Henry of Navarre was posthumously inducted into the <a href="National%20Museum%20of%20Racing%20and%20Hall%20of%20Fame">National Museum of Racing and Hall of Fame</a>. A painting by <a href="Gene%20Smith%20%28artist%29">Gene Smith</a> of Henry of Navarre in his 1894 match race against Domino can be seen at the Museum.
